title: HTTP HEAD requests cause Express server to terminate
body:
How to reproduce: 1. Run any of the examples: node examples/chat/app.js 2. Perform a HEAD request curl --head http://localhost:30000/ Uncaught exception, causes event loop to terminate. Console output: 
127.0.0.1 - - [05/Jul/2010 12:40:38] "HEAD / HTTP/1.1" 404 8164 0.0000
127.0.0.1 - - [05/Jul/2010 12:40:38] "HEAD / HTTP/1.1" 500 8164 0.0080
http:432
    throw new Error("This type of response MUST NOT have a body.");
          ^
Error: This type of response MUST NOT have a body.
    at ServerResponse.write (http:432:11)
    at lib/express/request.js:207:31
    at next (lib/express/request.js:334:9)
    at next (lib/express/request.js:340:11)
    at next (lib/express/request.js:338:11)
    at next (lib/express/request.js:340:11)
    at next (lib/express/request.js:340:11)
    at next (lib/express/request.js:340:11)
    at next (lib/express/request.js:340:11)
    at next (lib/express/request.js:340:11)

title: autoconversion of params
body:
I find it quite annoying that Express decides to convert inbound params, depending on their value. Especially if I have a password that's "1234" => then suddenly it's an integer.

Now auto-conversion is cool , but I think it's a bit cute at the moment

title: Serving static files via public seems slow
body:
Hi,

Serving static file via public seems slow, is there another way we could do it?

node.js/express    ---> http://screencast.com/t/MzcwNmVhZG (hosted on heroku.com)
php/codeigniter     ---> http://screencast.com/t/ZGFkNGJhZTMt (hosted on rackspace)

If we could sort this out node.js/express would blow php/codeigniter out of the water!  I've currently ported a bunch of the CI (codeigniter) app structure over to express to make it better for large apps and I'm also in the process of porting over http://codeigniter.com/user_guide/database/active_record.html I'll keep you posted on those.

title: submodule setup
body:
on the docs it says
cd express && git submodule update --init

this wasn't working for me. As I was not too familiar with submodules I was confused when it seemed to work but the folders for ext and sass etc were empty.
I suggest this line:
cd express && git submodule init && git submodule update

what am I doing wrong ?

title: Nodules compatibility
body:
Because the dynamic require for the renders engines, Express isn't compatible with nodules. Is possible to add an option where we can pass a reference with the loaded engine, so anyone who wants use nodules can avoid that dynamic require, loading the reference with a static path and then passing the render to express.

Thanks

title: delete cookie
body: It doesn't seem possible to delete a cookie value. I would expect something like : this.cookie("myval", null)

title: Cookie Parsing
body:
There's _either_ a bug with the writing out of cookies, or with the parsing of them;
 when the cookie value contains a '=' it gets truncated when express reads it back in :)

I'm sticking base64 encoded values into the cookie values, and sometimes those contain '=' 
I'm raising the bug to keep track of it, I'll fix it when I get a second.

title: use public as the default root for assets ?
body: Would it make sense to have /public as the default root for serving assets. E.g. /app.js would server out of /public/app.js. Might help not accidently serving up your express code ! (also saves typing /public alot!)

Under linux the html file contains suddenly the integer 1000 on the first line, and after roughly every 100 lines it puts another integer. (1000, 1000, 843, 0). On my Mac I have no such problem. Linux EC2: ubuntu-9.04-jaunty-base-64 Node v0.1.94 and Express version 0.11.0

title: EJS Partials not working
body:
When I call:

```
<%= this.partial("somepartial.html.ejs") %>
```

I get this:

```
500 TypeError: Object # has no method 'partial'
```

The issue is `this` is the `render` function in the view. The context has to be passed in when rendering.

I have a the fix and the updated specs in my fork. Will comment on this issue with the SHA.

title: Safari problem losing connection (long polling)
body: Using Express version 0.10.1, and Node v0.1.91, I somehow instantly disconnect in Safari from my long polling connection, without any errors, while there is no problem when I use Firefox or Chrome. Any idea on what might be causing this? I have no such problem using Express version 0.9.0

title: Mountable apps
body:
api could possibly be something like:
    var app = new express.Application
    app.get('/', function(){ ... })
    exports.app = app

then somewhere else:
     var app = new express.Application
     app.get('/', function(){ ... })
     app.mount('/blog', require('express-blog').app)

so '/' of blog would become /blog/

title: disable sessions for specific routes
body: Ideally sessions would be disabled for static assets being served by routes.  Something similar to the rails/sinatra way of doing this should be cool.

title: Refactor to Use Standard JavaScript Conventions
body:
Much of the coding style in Express looks as though it was inspired Ruby (lack of semicolons and braces around one line if-statements, 2-space tabs).  This deviates greatly from most other JavaScript projects, thus making it difficult to contribute code.

For more information, Douglas Crockford wrote up a set of "Code Conventions for the JavaScript Programming Language":
http://javascript.crockford.com/code.html

title: this.halt(200, '') sends a response body of 'OK'

title: allow customizing view engines
body: I'd like to add a :script filter to the haml parser so it doesn't output all of that pesky CDATA crap. No way to do it presently.

title: auto-reloading in development mode
body: Would be nice not to have to kill the process & restart every time the app is saved while in development mode. Not sure how this would be achieved (or if it's currently possible) in node.

title: reverse haml & sass file extension conventions
body:
Unless there's a good reason I'm not aware of, might I suggest that haml & sass files be named *.html.haml, *.xml.haml, *.sass (since sass always compiles to css), etc...

After all, a haml template IS a haml file, not an html file. Also: it doesn't needlessly differ from established conventions, and properly advises syntax highlighters. Haml-js could use the extension "hamljs" instead if they need to be discerned from their Ruby counterparts.

title: Pre-cache views like partials when "cache view contents"
body: which should probably be changed to "cache views" to match "cache view partials"

title: Support async view engines
body: and add asyncEJS / LESS / MU (or other mustache stuff)

title: Configurable route wildcard preprocessing / validation
body:
The most simple use-case I can think of is something like:
    get('/user/:number', function(id){}

where _:number_ would be mapped to a function using _parseInt()_,
if this fails then the route would _pass()_. Also _:id_ is common so
this could be an alias.

Another use-case would be to do something like:
    get('/user/:user_id', function(user){})

Where _:user_id_ could be mapped into loading the 
user's data instead of just an numeric id which would
be used to manually fetch the user each time..

Things to keep in mind:
- Must be async so that queries etc can occur
- Optional validation / passing support

title: Add LESS support when less.js is ready
Cache partials
body:
add:
    enable('cache view partials')

when enabled at boot Express will load partial
contents into cache to prevent calls to fs.readFileSync() which
is currently used allowing developers in "development" env to
quickly view changes.

This setting will be enabled by default for the "production" env

title: support for using jsontemplate as engine for views?
body: Support for json-template would be a good alternative to haml

title: consider using node-microseconds to logger
body: The logger plot timings aren't quite accurate enough. Some requests come in at 0.000ms; too fast for the logger. We may want to utilize: http://github.com/tmpvar/node-microseconds

title: Add sites / apps using Express section to site
Normalize naming conventions ... callback vs fn vs next etc
body:
we need to pick one lol I prefer "fn" since its small,
but it is not very descriptive, I think we should use "next"
when in a call chain, but use "callback" when its just a regular
async method

title: Static files not served when views cached under concurrent load test
body:
Hi, new to Express and just playing around with it a bit. I was working with the chat example app. I noticed the following:

1) Run chat server. 
2) Start a moderately concurrent load test with ab: 'ab -n10000 -c20 http://127.0.0.1:3000/'
3) Hit http://localhost:3000/ in your browser. The page loads fairly quickly.
4) Modify app.js to include enable('cache view contents') in the configure() callback
5) Stop ab, restart the server, start the ab again.
6) Hit http://localhost:3000/ in your browser. Observe in the resource timeline that '/' has loaded quickly, but app.js, style.css, and jquery.js are hung.
7) Stop ab
8) Observe that the static files come down immediately after stopping ab

On my machine, the server was serving '/' requests by ab in ~100ms. So you would reasonably expect to each browser request to be served fairly within 2s or so. However, I've let it run and after even 30s+ or sometimes the static file requests still have not been honored.
